p.style: margin: 0px 0px 6px; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; color: rgb(28, 30, 33); font-size: 14px;

span.style: font-size: medium; font-style: italic; white-space: pre-wrap; text-align: left; color: rgb(242, 242, 242);
span.strong: We realize that you have, and will continue to have many questions as we move forward. To help answer some of those questions, please see the Information and Updates Tab Below. The District realizes that questions will come up on a daily basis from parents and staff, along with situational changes. Therefore, we will continue to provide updates on a regular basis.

span.style: font-style: italic; white-space: pre-wrap; letter-spacing: 0.3px; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(242, 242, 242);

letter-spacing: 0.3px; font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(242, 242, 242);
font-style: italic; font-variant-numeric: normal; font-variant-east-asian: normal; vertical-align: baseline; white-space: pre-wrap; font-family: Arial; color: rgb(242, 242, 242);
text-align: center; font-size: medium; font-weight: bold; font-family: Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif; color: rgb(242, 242, 242);

strong.style: color: rgb(255, 255, 255); font-size: 10pt; font-family: Tahoma, Verdana, Arial, Helvetica;

span.style: background-color: rgb(238, 236, 225); font-family: Helvetica, sans-serif; font-size: 18px; color: rgb(0, 0, 0);

strong.span: All calls are to go to 746-1300

$(document).ready(function () {

        };

            {

                function activate() {
                    $(tabObj).scrollingTabs({                 
                        tabs: [{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_0","title":"Information and Updates","content":"
As we have heard from the Governor's Office, NYS Schools are now closed through May 15, 2020. Before that deadline, the Governor will make another determination whether or not he will extend past that date.

In addition, the NYS Regents have cancelled the June 2020 regents exams.  Here is the Regents Guidance Document





Thank you for your patience and understanding as we work through the daily changes.





The Latest Information and Updates

 and answers to common questions:

Click for:Emergency Communication Document







","active":true,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_1","title":"Learning Guidelines","content":"


Overview

March
13, 2020 was our last day of in-school classes with our students.  At that
time, the administrative team asked teachers to send work home with
students that would review prior learning and help eliminate
regression.  All students K-12 were provided Chromebooks, and many began the
journey into teaching classes online.  Since that time, administrators
across the DCMO BOCES region have been asked to define what that online
instruction should look like going past this review period, how long
instruction should last each day, and what that will look like in each
individual district.  Below please find our guidelines. 

Curriculum

Curriculum
will prioritize NYS learning standards and cover essential curriculum as instruction
is provided.  As a grade level or subject area team, the focus will be on
standards that are foundational for future learning in other courses or grade
levels.  The curriculum will be pared down, providing students exposure to
and instruction in the most important standards.  

Teachers of Regents courses will continue to provide students with
instruction focused on remaining content for the school year. Regents Exams for June 2020 are cancelled.
However, the learning in these classes will be the foundation for future
coursework.



Teachers of AP courses will follow the information provided by The
College Board, which is developing AP tests for this year that will cover
content taught through early March. 



Teachers of college courses should follow instructions they
receive from the college/university.



Instruction

All teachers in grades K-8 will be working in teams. As a grade
level they will be deciding what to teach and sharing lessons. Special Education
students will need to have their accommodations and modifications as per their
IEP. Special Education teachers will work with the regular education teachers
to provide those services. 



Teachers
in grades 9-12 and Accelerated 8th Grade - All students must be able to
participate in each of his or her classes.  Therefore, teachers may
utilize asynchronous teaching, meaning they record lessons or send out directions
through Google Classroom so that students have flexibility of working whenever
they are available to work on the lesson.  Teachers may also continue to
schedule synchronous or “live” meetings as well.  Teachers are using a schedule for that to avoid
overlap and conflicting times for students.  

Time
Allocations 

The
following are time expectations for students' at home learning.  Such
learning includes learning new material through direct
teaching (both synchronous and asynchronous), participating in classroom
discussions and feedback, and completing assigned work and activities. 
Review and practice of new material can be in addition to this time, but we
will utilize the "less is more" rule of thumb.  We will not add
more than one hour total on the weekly total for review and practice.  

·  K-2: 
1 hour and 15 minutes per week for ELA, 1 hour and 15 per week minutes for
Math, 1 additional hour per week for learning in other subject areas (3.5 hours
total maximum) 

·  3-5: 
2 hours per week for ELA, 2 hours per week for Math,  1
additional hour per week for learning in other subject areas  (5 hours
total maximum)

Please know for elementary, the limit of 1
additional hour per week for learning in other subject areas will mean that your
child will get a 10-12 minute lesson each week from each of the specials
teachers (Art, Music, PE, Health, Library, STEAM 3-5)

·  6-8: 
2 hours per week for ELA, 2 hours per week for Math, 2 hours per week for
science, 2 hours per week for Social Studies, 2 additional hours per week for
learning in other subject areas (10 hours total maximum) 

·  9-12: 
3 hours per week for each credit bearing course (24 hours per week total
maximum)

 

 

 




","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_2","title":"Elementary","content":"","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_3","title":"Food Service","content":"




The Delivery Team

Delaware academy is offering free meal service for all students. This service includes breakfast and lunch at no cost.

About this service.  
How Do I sign up?
Sign Up by using this form:  Emergency Food Service Request
By Contacting the district at 746-1300.
What do I get in my meal?
Beginning on Monday March 23rd, the Emergency Feeding Program will move to a Monday/Wednesday delivery and pickup status. 



Monday's delivery/pickup will consist of a Monday lunch, Tuesday breakfast, Tuesday lunch, and a Wednesday breakfast. 



Wednesday's delivery/pickup will consist of Wednesday's lunch, Thursday breakfast, Thursday lunch, Friday breakfast, Friday lunch, and breakfast for the following Monday. 



All students enrolled in the backpack feeding program will receive their food on Wednesday of each week.
Tell me about the Pickup Option
When sign up for meal pickup, you will be picking up meals on Monday and Wednesday. Meals can be picked up at the High School Cafeteria- please follow the signs in the parking lot. Pickup times are from 11 AM to 1 PM .
If I Chose Delivery, when should I expect the food? 
A rough estimate for delivery will be between the hours of 10:30 AM and 2 PM on Monday and Wednesday.


How is this program being funded?

This is being fully funded though the existing Free and Reduced lunch program.  The eligibility guidelines were changed by Federal and state programs so that ALL students are now eligible. 








 





","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_4","title":"Superintendent Search","content":"
Superintendent Brochure

Superintendent Application 





","active":false,"disabled":false},{"paneId":"ctl00_ContentPlaceHolder1_ctl16_divTabs_5","title":"Tech Support","content":"Technology Support 






    
        

             Frequently asked questions:
             Contacting Support:  

            

            Please use the Technical Support Form  to submit your question/need.
        
        

             If I do not have a charger or lost my chromebook, what do I do?

            Submit a Technical Support Request

            
             Technical Support Form
        
        

            During the school closure, will there be a charge for chromebook repairs or chargers?  

            We ask that you take care of the chromebook to the best of your ability, and understand that breakage will happen.  If something happens, contact us and we'll get your problem resolved for no charge during this closing. 
             E-mail:

            support@delhischools.org
        
        

             what is the ending of my username?

            for students it is @dacsd.org
             
        
        

            I forgot my password, How can I get it reset? Submit a Technical Support Request and we'll give you a call back to verify some information before we reset your password. 
             For secuirty purposes we will not share passwords via e-mail

p.span: Notice is hereby given that the annual inspection for 2020 of the school buildings of Delaware Academy Central School District at Delhi for fire hazards which might endanger the lives of students, teachers, employees therein, has been completed and the report thereof is available at the office of Buildings and Grounds at 2 Sheldon Drive, Delhi, New York for inspection by all interested persons.
